citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is one adult female albino wallaby at the facility that is in need of veterinary care. Around 5 pm on 6/4/2025, APHIS
Officials identified the wallaby which appeared lethargic with an unkempt coat and a thin body condition. She was found
lying listless in the prone position with her eyes closed against the back wall of the enclosure while the rest of the
wallabies were active. Upon closer monitoring, the wallaby was observed to have a swollen area on the underside of the
right jaw. The wallaby was also seen opening and closing its mouth, sticking out its tongue, and smacking its lips
repeatedly. When asked, the facility stated that none of the staff had noticed this wallaby’s condition.
Inadequate daily observations and failure to observe medical problems can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals
when injuries or changes in their health or behavior are not noticed in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all
animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication with the attending veterinarian. The facility must obtain veterinary care for this wallaby.
To be corrected by close of business on June 5, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first.

There is a section of the perimeter fence at the back of the property that does not connect, creating a large opening. This
incomplete section of fence leaves the two giant anteaters without a perimeter fence. The facility fixed this gap during the
inspection.
An insufficient or incomplete perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially
harm the animals within. An incomplete perimeter fence is also not able to act as secondary containment for the animals
and can lead to escape. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the
facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient
height (at least six feet high) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least
three feet) from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure
and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 03 AUG 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is one adult female albino wallaby at the facility that is in need of veterinary care. Around 5 pm on 6/4/2025, APHIS 
Officials identified the wallaby which appeared lethargic with an unkempt coat and a thin body condition. She was found 
lying listless in the prone position with her eyes closed against the back wall of the enclosure while the rest of the 
wallabies were active. Upon closer monitoring, the wallaby was observed to have a swollen area on the underside of the 
right jaw. The wallaby was also seen opening and closing its mouth, sticking out its tongue, and smacking its lips 
repeatedly. When asked, the facility stated that none of the staff had noticed this wallaby’s condition.  
Inadequate daily observations and failure to observe medical problems can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals 
when injuries or changes in their health or behavior are not noticed in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all 
animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent 
communication with the attending veterinarian. The facility must obtain veterinary care for this wallaby. 
To be corrected by close of business on June 5, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is a section of the perimeter fence at the back of the property that does not connect, creating a large opening. This 
incomplete section of fence leaves the two giant anteaters without a perimeter fence. The facility fixed this gap during the 
inspection. 
An insufficient or incomplete perimeter fence can allow unwanted animals or people to enter the facility and potentially 
harm the animals within. An incomplete perimeter fence is also not able to act as secondary containment for the animals 
and can lead to escape. The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by 
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the 
facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient 
height (at least six feet high) to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. It must be of sufficient distance (at least 
three feet) from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure 
and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 03 AUG 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
